contained.name: is_integral
contained.title: is_integral
contained.description: True if the `_numerator_` and `_denominator_` values are integers, i.e. if `_precision_` is 0.

contained.name: add
contained.title: add
contained.description: Sum of two strictly comparable proportions.

contained.name: subtract
contained.title: subtract
contained.description: Difference between two strictly comparable proportions.

contained.name: is_equal
contained.title: is_equal
contained.description: Return True if this `DV_AMOUNT` is considered equal to `_other_`.

contained.name: less_than
contained.title: less_than
contained.description: True if this Proportion is less than  `_other_`. Only valid if `_is_strictly_comparable_to()_` is True.

contained.name: is_strictly_comparable_to
contained.title: is_strictly_comparable_to
contained.description: Return True if the `_type_` of this proportion is the same as the `_type_` of `_other_`.

name: DV_PROPORTION
title: DV_PROPORTION
description:
Models a ratio of values, i.e. where the numerator and denominator are both pure numbers. The `_valid_proportion_kind_` property of the `PROPORTION_KIND` class is used to control the type attribute to be one of a defined set.

Used for recording titers (e.g. 1:128), concentration ratios, e.g. Na:K (unitary denominator), albumin:creatinine ratio, and percentages, e.g. red cell distirbution width (RDW). 
 
Misuse: Should not be used to represent things like blood pressure which are often written using a  '/' character, giving the misleading impression that the item is a ratio, when in fact it is a structured value. Similarly, visual acuity, often written as (e.g.) "6/24" in clinical notes is not a ratio but an ordinal (which includes non-numeric symbols like CF = count fingers etc). Should not be used for formulations.

element.short: Models a ratio of values, i.
element.definition:
Models a ratio of values, i.e. where the numerator and denominator are both pure numbers. The `_valid_proportion_kind_` property of the `PROPORTION_KIND` class is used to control the type attribute to be one of a defined set.

Used for recording titers (e.g. 1:128), concentration ratios, e.g. Na:K (unitary denominator), albumin:creatinine ratio, and percentages, e.g. red cell distirbution width (RDW). 
 
Misuse: Should not be used to represent things like blood pressure which are often written using a  '/' character, giving the misleading impression that the item is a ratio, when in fact it is a structured value. Similarly, visual acuity, often written as (e.g.) "6/24" in clinical notes is not a ratio but an ordinal (which includes non-numeric symbols like CF = count fingers etc). Should not be used for formulations.

constraint.human: Precision validity must satisfy conditional constraints
Is integral validity must satisfy conditional constraints
constraint.expression: is_integral() implies (numerator.floor = numerator and denominator.floor = denominator)

constraint.human: Fraction validity must satisfy conditional constraints
constraint.expression: (type = pk_fraction or type = pk_integer_fraction) implies is_integral()

constraint.human: Unitary validity must satisfy conditional constraints
Percent validity must satisfy conditional constraints

element.short: Indicates semantic type of proportion, including percent, unitary etc.
element.definition: Indicates semantic type of proportion, including percent, unitary etc.

element.short: Precision  to  which  the  `_numerator_` and `_denominator_` values of  the  proportion are expressed, in terms of number  of decimal places.
element.definition: Precision  to  which  the  `_numerator_` and `_denominator_` values of  the  proportion are expressed, in terms of number  of decimal places. The value 0 implies an integral quantity. The value -1 implies no limit, i.e. any number of decimal places.

element.short: Optional tagged other reference ranges for this value in its particular measurement context.
element.definition: Optional tagged other reference ranges for this value in its particular measurement context.
